message.content:
A complex SSH command!

Here's a breakdown of what this command does:

1. `ssh`: The command to establish a secure shell connection.
2. `-i "~/UserKey.pem"`: Specifies the private key file to use for authentication. In this case, it's a relative path (`~/`) pointing to a file named `UserKey.pem` in the user's home directory.
3. `-C`: Enables compression of all data sent over the connection.
4. `-L 25900:localhost:5900`: Sets up a local port forward (tunnel). This tells SSH to:
	* Listen on a local port (`25900`) on your machine.
	* Forward incoming connections on that port to `localhost:5900`. In other words, any traffic sent to `localhost:25900` will be forwarded to `ec2-34-221-131-108.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com:5900`.
5. `user@ec2-34-221-131-108.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com`: Specifies the remote host and user to connect to. In this case, it's a EC2 instance on Amazon Web Services (AWS) with an IP address of `ec2-34-221-131-108.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com`. The `user` part is the username for the remote account.

When you run this command:

* SSH will use the private key file (`~/UserKey.pem`) to authenticate you as `user` on the EC2 instance.
* It will set up a local port forward (tunnel) from your machine's port 25900 to the EC2 instance's port 5900.
* Any traffic sent to `localhost:25900` on your machine will be forwarded to `ec2-34-221-131-108.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com:5900`.

This is often used for remote desktop access, as it allows you to tunnel a secure connection from your local machine to the EC2 instance and connect to a remote desktop service (e.g., VNC) running on port 5900.
